reviewText: It's hard to find a good OLD movie now days. These are just that. I love old movies and enjoyed adding these to my collection.
haven't seen these movies for a long long  time and it was great to see them again.  funny and entertaining.

The Walking Nightmare is the best of these two as for picture and sound. The movie itself is a good collection. I see a lot of post
about The Ghost Walks which leaves one to believe the picture and sound is bad, well the picture is OK. The problem is the sound.
The answer, just turn up the volume and enjoy a great old movie from way back.

If you know Monogram than you know A WALKING NIGHTMARE because it's the same movie as their THE LIVING GHOST. Which is not to say it's bad, but just be aware. The Alpha print of this one is pretty good but the other THE GHOST WALKS is really really bad, it looks like a third generation of a faded, splice-ridden print. That's the one I really wanted to see and I stopped watching after five minutes. And that says a lot since I grew up on third generation dupes of faded, splice-ridden prints of MOnogram horrors....

This ALPHA VIDEO double feature consists of 'B' grade horror programmers from Hollywood's golden age of limburger. SYNOPSES-- THE GHOST WALKS-- A stormy night and a car that skids off a remote road force a playwright and his secretary to take refuge in a creepy mansion. Dinner guests invited on the first anniversary of the homeowner's violent death discuss his murder. Then, the lights go out..... A WALKING NIGHTMARE-- This was the working title of a film ultimately released as "The Living Ghost." An investigator finds that the wealthy kidnap victim he's been searching for has been turned into a sort of zombie. THE HAT BOX MYSTERY/HOLLYWOOD MYSTERY is another unusual two-fer from ALPHA VIDEO. Parenthetical numbers preceding titles are 1 to 10 viewer poll ratings found at a film resource website. (6.2) The Ghost Walks (1934) - John Miljan/June Collyer/Richard Carle/Henry Kolker/Johnny Arthur/Spencer Charters (5.5) A Walking Nightmare ("The Living Ghost") (1942) - James Dunn/Joan Woodbury/Paul McVey/Vera Gordon/Norman Willis/Minerva Urecal
